title: Beyond Active Noun Tagging: Modeling Contextual Interactions for Multi-Class Active Learning

author: Behjat Siddiquie, Department of Computer Science, University of Maryland

segmentation: Good morning, I'm magically from the University of Maryland and I'll talk about my paper titled Beyond Active Down Tagging.
Modeling contextual interactions for multiclass active learning.
So before starting the talk, I'll give you an introduction about this talk is about.
Um?
We propose an active learning approach for scene understanding problems.
In scene understanding, the goal is to identify all the different objects present in an image.
And scene understanding is a much more difficult problem as compared to image classification problems, where each image consists of just a single object.
There are two main contributions of our work.
The first contribution is that we propose a new criterion for active selection of regions called image entropy.
Here originally selected based on the information it provides about itself as well as the information it provides about other regions in the image.
The second contribution is that we introduce new ways of collecting knowledge by proposing to new kinds of questions.
The first kind of questions are called linguistic questions.
Here, given an image, the system uses high confidence detections as anchors to ask questions about other regions in the image.
For example, in this case, the robot recognizes the floor and it can use floor as an anchor to ask a question such as.
What is on the floor?
The second kind of questions are contextual questions.
In scene understanding tasks, learning the relationships between pairs of objects is very important.
And.
We propose contextual questions too explicitly as the user relationship questions.

For example, instead of learning the relationship between a pair of objects from thousands of labeled images, we can instead ask the user questions such as what is the relationship between Sky and grass?
Before going into into the details, I'll give you a motivation of why active learning is required.
For building a scene understanding system consisting of an objects, we need to learn order and appearance models and order and square relationship models.
And change the number of object categories and is very large.
This is a very challenging problem.

Due to these reasons, randomly annotating training data is extremely inefficient and we need more efficient ways of annotating data.
This brings us to active learning.
The goal of active learning is to learn the best possible classifier while having to annotate the least amount of data.
Given a pool of unlabeled samples, an active learner iteratively chooses sample.
Vision annotation provide them.
Some amount of information.
Active learning has been done for binary classification problems.

But since we are going to see an understanding, we need to actively learn an appearance model as well as a relationship model.
I'll now describe our approach.
Many active learning methods adopted uncertainty based approach.
Here.
The assumption is that the region that the classifier finds the most uncertain will provide the maximum information.
And these methods typically select the region.
The most uncertain region based on based on its appearance.

We propose a new criterion called image entropy, where a region is selected for labeling based on based on the uncertainty in its appearance as well as the uncertainty in the contextual relationships of that region with other regions in the image.
Let's see an example of how image entropy can be better than region entropy.
Consider a system which has an appearance model of both water entry and it also knows that both occurs on water.

On the other hand, an image entropy based method will select a different boat.

Is water.
And then you can further infer that other objects on water boats.
And therefore from a single labeling question it can learn the appearance of multiple kinds of birds, and this speeds up the process of active learning.
Or given any image segmented into multiple regions.
It can be enabled by signing an object label to each region.
We define the image entropy as the entropy over the probabilities of all possible labelings of the image.
And since the number of labelings of the image is exponential, we use the 2nd order approximation of entropy.
So this is our active learning framework or training data set is divided into a very large unlabeled set and a small initially label set.
The initially label set is used to learn the preliminary classifier.
Then at each round of active learning we generate sets of questions of all of many of multiple types, and among all these questions we select the best question.
The user then answers the question and the model is updated and this process continues.
We ask the user three kinds of questions.

Region labeling questions, linguistic questions, and contextual questions, and at each stage of active learning from among possible questions of all these three types, we need to select, we need to select the question that will improve the model the most.
